{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3173996,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-27T14:01:20.735Z","cooked":"

The competitions we (6500) attended here in NC seemed to have a larger-than-normal rate of glitchiness with robots on the field, usually after an impact. Neglecting radio issues (since @marshall already started that thread) what other best practices can you share regarding good, reliable wiring?

I can share what we did this year, with the comment that our robot had zero glitches vs last year’s twitchy mess at States.

  1. Used the BrainBoxes Ethernet switch

    • the switches we used previously had various issues with coming apart under impact, or unreliable power connections, or both. This one was rock solid.

  2. Used spring type connectors for switch power and RoboRIO power

    • Screw clamp connectors are (IMO) unreliable under heavy shock / vibration. I handed out several RIO spring power connectors this year, and for next year I’ll stock up on spring connectors for the RIO and switch to give out as swag.

  3. Pull tested every non-factory-crimped connection and some factory crimped ones

    • We found several subpar Anderson crimps which were corrected before comp.

  4. Wire management and strain relief applied to all connections and wiring runs

    • Used LOTS of zip ties, sticky squares, and (when we had to) duct tape to ensure that all wires are supported near their connection points but not putting strain on the actual connection. This included CAN bus, Ethernet cables, sensor cables and power wires.

  5. Used REV RPM, with a new good quality Ethernet cable

  • Pure speculation here, but I think the 18v output from the RPM vs the 12v output of the VRM made for a more stable radio. It might just be the good cable though.
  1. Limited our ferrule use to only PDP main power
  • This will be controversial. This year we only used ferrules on the 12 AWG power wires to the PDP. In previous years we’d put ferrules on the smaller wires for RIO power, VRM, PCM, switch power - and some of those ferrules came loose.
    This year we stripped 18 AWG wires to the correct length, carefully twisted the strands to be sure nothing was loose, and then made sure they were tight in their spring connectors with no exposed copper or stray strands.
    My opinion here is that the ferrules only help with loose strands and are not ideal for the small Weidmuller style spring connectors. Using a stripper like this Knipex one (https://www.amazon.com/Automatic-Wire-Stripper-10-24-AWG/dp/B003B8WB5U/) where you can set the length makes things easier to get right. The connectors like bare wire best, no solder or ferrule.
  1. Used locks on all lockable connectors
  • CAN bus connections were locked together with these: PWM Cable Clip - 10 Pack - REV Robotics
  • Andersons were locked together with zip ties (yes I know there are official Anderson locks, zip ties are cheaper)
  • Ethernet cables had good quality locking tabs or got tossed
  • USB cable extender for the camera got duct tape
  1. Hot Glue (small amounts) on all non-locking connectors
  • If it didn’t have a positive latch and was held together only by friction, it got a dab of hot glue. This covered the Ethernet switch power connector, Raspberry Pi power connector, encoder cables (motor, through bore, and adapter), CAN cables on our Spark Maxes (VERY carefully), and anything that plugged into the RIO that didn’t have screws.

Love to hear other teams’ ideas on reliable wiring

-Ben

I wrote this a few years ago. A couple things have changed since then but all of the suggestions are still good ideas.

Your Team Sucks At Electronics: Here's Why General Forum
If this is going to be a thing, then let’s keep it going. This is following on similar posts about scouting, programming, defense, and being rookies. Hi, I’m Ari. I was in charge of electronics on my high school team, mentor the electronics sub-team on my current team, and have been volunteering as a CSA for 3 years (with 15 competitions as a CSA under my belt). I’ve seen my fair share of robots dying from all kinds of electronics problems. Here are some of the more common ones that might be hi…

We had previously been using Rev clips for our CAN connections and were having serious problems with reliability heading into this year’s competition. Not really a flaw with the Rev clips - just DuPont flakiness. We switched to these IDC connectors and found them to be really solid. We exchanged some serious hits and the robot never flinched electrically.

amazon.com

Low Voltage Wire Connectors, Brightfour 12 Pack Quick Solderless Wire Splice...

Low Voltage Wire Connectors, Brightfour 12 Pack Quick Solderless Wire Splice Connector, 2 Way Automotive Wire Connectors, Reliable Connection Small Wire Connectors I Type 2 Pins, Fits 20-24 AWG - - Amazon.com

$10.98

The only issue we still struggle with is the connector on the Rio for the RSL. Any suggestions? Just glue the sucker in?

Similar to the connectors you’ve linked, we’ve run these connectors from WCP for the last 2 years now, and absolutely love them!

I haven’t seen anything that beats Deutch connectors. The crimper isn’t cheap but it make an outstanding crimp. They aren’t cheap.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-27T18:30:42.046Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":47.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431922,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring/431922/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3174386,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-27T18:31:01.554Z","cooked":"

We just glued the RSL connector in, yeah. Same with the encoder cables in DIO ports.

We have had bad luck with IDC connectors and no issues with the premade DuPont ones on the Spark Max CAN cables. The lever spring connectors seem better than either.

One additional thing with IDC - they are typically only good for one or two “crimps” before the metal distorts and the connection gets flaky.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-27T19:21:37.064Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":209,"readers_count":208,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":431922,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49671,"username":"WitchKing","name":"L J Brackney","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/witchking/{size}/160264_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring/431922/6","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3174398,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-27T18:39:54.812Z","cooked":"

The keys to reliable crimped connections of any type (Anderson, duPont, ferrules, etc) are a very high quality crimping tool, sized for the wire and crimp you’re using, with high quality correct size crimp pins, and lots of practice. Using the factory made ones makes it less of a crapshoot.
We absolutely stink at crimping anything that isn’t an Anderson or a large ferrule, probably because of tool quality issues and practice.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-27T18:39:54.812Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":24,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":158.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431922,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring/431922/7","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3174474,"name":"Drakxii","username":"Drakxii","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/4da419/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-27T19:59:23.994Z","cooked":"
beedward:
  1. Used spring type connectors for switch power and RoboRIO power

Do you have a link to this?

Also for 6. in my experience it depends on the strands of the wire. Some of the extra flexible/high strand wires have strands thin enough that they can be really hard to push into a spring connector and the retention isn’t great. Wires with thicker strands don’t have these issues but can be a pain to run/deal with elsewhere in the robot. Also for small ferrules make sure to use a four way crimper instead of a 6, they retain better in my experience.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-03-27T20:00:48.497Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":85.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431922,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring","display_username":"Drakxii","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23134,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI "},"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-reliable-robot-wiring/431922/8","custom_user_title":"2582/5941 Mentor, CSA, and RI ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3174514,"name":"Ben Edwards","username":"beedward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beedward/{size}/111315_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-27T20:40:05.399Z","cooked":"

RoboRIO connector: https://www.andymark.com/products/roborio-power-phoenix-push-in-spring-connector
or
https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/phoenix-contact/1748354/4451742

Ethernet switch connector: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/phoenix-contact/1110582/15211615

I would have preferred lever action for both, but I couldn’t find one for the smaller connector that goes on the RIO.

I just checked with Phoenix Contact, they do actually have a lever action version now but it’s not in distribution yet. Look up Phoenix Contact 1849049
